title.narrative: IR 2.3: RELEVANT CORE COMMITTMENTS

description.narrative: IR 2.3: Relevant Core Commitments on Education are met in all humanitarian settings, which contributes to Education In Emergencies, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Operations Support To Programme Delivery, Technical Excellence In Policy And Programmes. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: PCR2. National, community based organizations/groups and schools offer quality active civic engagement programmes for adolescents to learn, develop and participate

System strengthening - risk informed programming, including climate, resilience, disaster, conflict, and emergency preparedness

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: IR 2.3: Relevant Core Commitments on Education are met in all humanitarian settings
Education needs assessments are conducted in both Host Communities and Camps

actual.value: 2014:Two education needs assessments in host communities and camps have been conducted, led by UNICEF in collaboration with the Education Sector Working Group. The Joint Education Needs Assessment for Za'atari has been completed and published in October 2014. The Joint Education Needs Assessment for the

title.narrative: Number of community members with information relevant to education and referral services

actual.value: 2014:300,000 refugees in camps and host communities were reached by Back to School campaign

title.narrative: Number of trainings conducted targeting MoE, new teachers and service providers

target.value: 2014:3000 newly recruited teachers (primary/secondary) and service providers

actual.value: 2014:Nearly 2400 teachers in schools in camps and double-shifted schools in host communities have been trained in 2014. Trainings focused on the new curricula for grades 1 to 3, instructional games and interactive learning, new teaching and learning techniques

title.narrative: Number of children and youth benefitting from alternative (informal and non-formal) education

actual.value: 2014:23,342 children assisted with informal education and basic life skills in Camps and Host Communities, since January 2014, through 8 UNICEF implementing partners. The implementation of Non-formal education projects was delayed due to administrative approvals

title.narrative: Availability of IM system and consolidated and updated 3W matrix

baseline.value: 3W matrix for Zaatari camp and host community available

target.value: 2014:Revised and updated 3W matrix for Host Community and Camps

actual.value: 2014:Progress in this area has been slower than expected due to delays in the recruitment of an IM Officer. Nevertheless, the different tasks and responsibilities have been taken care of by UNICEF colleagues in different sections (PM&E, Education) and by Associate IM Officers at UNHCR. Tasks completed in

title.narrative: Number of Children (girls and boys) with access to pyscho-social support in school settings
Number of Children provided with individual education kits (school bags and stationary)

actual.value: 2014:UNICEF with the logistical support of Save the Children provided individual education kits (school bags) to some 130,000 school-going children in camps and host communities (70% Syrians and 30% vulnerable Jordanians, 49% boys and 51% girls). In addition, UNICEF provided essential education supplies

title.narrative: Number of School-aged children (girls and boys) in affected areas with access to schools/learning programmes
Availability of effective working group coordination mechanism for Education in humanitarian setting

target.value: 2014:No. of working group meetings held, No. of Organizations/agencies participating in Edu working group, Availability of Coordination mechanism framework and TOR duly and endorsed by the working group, E

actual.value: 2014:During 2014, the Education Sector Working Group (ESWG) led by UNICEF achieved the following: Bi-weekly meetings (with accompanied minutes) in Amman and Za'atari, 40 organisations/agencies,Two Joint Education Needs assessment conducted (Za'atari Camp and Host Communities), 4Ws Partner mapping exerc

title.narrative: Availability of education standards and guidelines contextualized

target.value: 2014:Handbook of Jordan INEE MS is contextualized and translated in both English and Arabic

actual.value: 2014:Training on INEE Minimum Standards was conducted and the process of contextualisation has been initiated. Translation of handbook in both English and Arabic will be finalised in early 2015
